p: Every year, an estimated two million tons of chemical pesticides are used on crops worldwide [ 1]. Their excessive use has caused significant environmental damage and compromised public health due to their toxic, non-biodegradable properties and the accumulation of residues in soil, water, and food [ 2, 3]. Thus, studies focusing on alternatives to pesticides have increased in recent years [ 4, 5, 6]. Plant essential oils are promising alternatives due to their biodegradability, lower toxicity to nontarget organisms, and maintenance of ecological balance [ 7]. For this reason, essential oils have been termed “green pesticides” [ 3].
